First off, it has several new slides and play areas that are super fun! My kids loved the step slides and the tube slide. The workers here today were awesome. Friendly and attentive helping to boost our experience. One of them helped make the tube slide more slick and even won stuffed animals from the claw machines for each of my kids! It is clean and not over crowded like the one in Bluffdale often is but that could just be because we came on the 4th. Also they had a Mother's room which was amazing. It was clean and the nursing chair was comfortable. I love the space theme too! There were a few things that didn't work like the ball cannon and a free others which was slightly disappointing since it's so new but overall didn't hinder our experience. Lastly, my 3 year old wandered off and got lost and the workers found her remembered she belonged to me and found me quickly. Overall we had a stellar experience! Very impressed! â  â ----------------------- â  â Reviewer: Nicole Wakefield â Rating: 3/5 â Time: 2 months ago â Review: This is definitely a super cool indoor playground! I have to say though - this place is severely under staffed and the equipment needs way more supervision. In the span of the 2 hours we were there, we saw multiple kids get hurt due to the extremely steep slides and not knowing how to go down them with the pad/tube or too many kids going at once. There really should be someone ensuring the safety of others. The bathrooms were also super unattended - trash overflowing, lots of wet spots. Overall it was clean (it's new) and super unique compared to other indoor playgrounds but they absolutely need more supervision and staff otherwise serious injury will absolutely occur. If you bring your kids, be sure to watch them closely or follow them on the equipment. â  â ----------------------- â  â Reviewer: Megan Jimenez â Rating: 5/5 â Time: 2 months ago â Review: I am so happy Kidtopia is here in Spanish Fork! Once you are inside it is truly astonishing how many things they can fit into this place. It is very clean, bright, and the atmosphere was good. The employees were attentive, quick, and kind. They have a lot of seating options for parents/spectators to watch the children---but also have the option for parents to join their kids which I greatly appreciated. Their slides were amazing, and my son had a blast on them! He also loved the obstacle course they have! The metal slides were probably his favorite along with the tube slide. He also loved to play the claw machines and the prizes in them were great! I can absolutely see the value in having the monthly pass which is what we signed him up for-but their punch cards are also very reasonable! My son is really wanting to have his birthday party here, so that may have to happen this year! For those who have smaller children they have a whole section dedicated to them, and it looks really cute and fun for kids. Our son is nearly 8 so he did not go into this area, but I also appreciated that it is blocked off to ensure that larger kids are not running into the smaller children. We will of course definitely be returning! â  â ----------------------- â  â Reviewer: Kassidy Akkula â Rating: 3/5 â Time: 2 months ago â Review: CONS: Customer service was poor. Said we didn't need gripper socks but then later told us we needed them. The teens didn't know the policy I guess.  Had to pay extra for that. â  â They have these gates that you need wrist bands to go through that are not very kid friendly. Ive seen so many kids cry trying to get in and out and the gates wont open or they shut on you. They've squished so many kids behind them too when they open. â  â And it is overpriced.  Charging for children not even 1 years old is kinda ridiculous considering half the time a baby isn't even playing. â  â PROS: On the bright side - the place is great for kids to play and has plenty of things to do for all ages (except for 1 and under). I do like the containment but the gates are annoying for the little kids. â  â My only complaints was the poor customer service and the price. The staff was great, it was a fun place, pretty clean, and pretty good equipment - though it's not well lit, the drinking fountains were broken, and it was pretty cold inside. We had fun playing for my son's birthday party, but their party policies are unclear and confusing. Nowhere, when I booked the party (which includes entrance for 10 kids), did it say you can only arrive 5 minutes prior to the room reservation, which I didn't appreciate because I wanted to schedule the room for 5:00pm but couldn't because that wasn't an option (even though no one had the room booked before us) and we wanted to start the party then and play before eating pizza and cake at 6:00 (playing before eating, so kids don't get sick). It took several phone calls and convincing the manager to let us play before our room reservation (even though when we got there, there was almost no one else there). The website and signs on the door say "No outside food or drink", but then there is a place to eat food and the other guests I saw there were eating outside food, so it's stated everywhere but not enforced? For the party, we couldn't bring outside food (aside from the cake and water bottles), and had to order through them. BUT they only offered a couple kinds of pizza, and it turns out, they just go buy it from Marco's in Lindon. Good pizza, but why couldn't I buy it from Marco's or anywhere else myself and bring it in? Then I would've been able to have more choices than just pepperoni or cheese pizza. Plus, the staff member who went to pick it up got lost so we couldn't start our pizza party in the room until 25 minutes after our scheduled time anyway (poor kids were getting hungry). I asked if we could bring in a veggie or fruit tray (minimal mess and something healthy) and they absolutely refused saying it was against policy, but they don't offer anything healthy, just the pizza and juice boxes. I assumed they would have enough plates for us since we ordered 8 pizzas, but they only provided 10 plates for the kids (I guess adults don't get plates). I didn't know so I didn't bring our own and then they charge 50 cents a paper plate if you want any extras. It's truly wild! So yeah, the play place is safe and fun for the kids to play, but their party policies are nuts and don't make any sense, so I can't fully recommend it, for a birthday party, at least. â And FYI, the party rooms are pretty small so the kids fit fine but the adults were crowded around the edges just standing with only a few able to sit. â  â ----------------------- â  â Reviewer: Rebecca Peterson â Rating: 5/5 â Time: 7 months ago â Review: My toddler loved this place, very clean and friendly staff. â  â ----------------------- â  â Reviewer: Courtney Bengry â Rating: 3/5 â Time: 8 months ago â Review: Visited for our first time today and my kids absolutely loved it, itâ€™s clean and my kids could have spent all day here, however, the only thing that was disappointing was it isnâ€™t allergy friendly. So if you have an uneven number of kids like me (ages 5, 2, 1) the second kid under 2 will be $6 admission. â  â For me, I have a punch pass. I like the punch pass. But the punch pass is NOT a good value if used on $6 admissions for under 2 yrs old (at least not in the current pricing structure for April 2025). â  â So now that I understand the policy, I'd recommend buying the punch pass for the full-price siblings (ages 3+) but pay the $6 out-of-pocket for any odd number 2-and-under younger siblings rather than using a punch on them. reviews: {Reviewer: Kenzie Ivory â Rating: 3/5 â Time: a week ago â Review: Fun place for my 4 year old and 18 month old and it can keep them busy for hours! We mostly like to play outside in the summers but we love that they have a trampoline we can use and lots of things to climb on. It keeps my kids entertained and they love it here. I've been here a few times and I actively watch them and follow them to make sure they are safe and I personally think it is gross. Staff are teenagers that aren't very friendly and play on their phones the entire time. The 3 times I've been there I saw someone "clean" once. The girl just sprayed benches people weren't sitting on without wiping them down which isn't really cleaning. I also never personally saw them clean the playground. I don't know what their cleaning expectations are but I've been to other indoor playgrounds before I moved here that had employees go into the play area every hour with spray and cloths to wipe down the equipment and it always smelled clean. We will go here again most likely but I wish their staff would actually work and make the place a clean and friendly atmosphere like I'm sure the owners expect them and pay them to do. â  â ----------------------- â  â Reviewer: Maria Granados â Rating: 2/5 â Time: 3 weeks ago â Review: N/A â  â ----------------------- â  â Reviewer: Jessica K Smith â Rating: 4/5 â Time: a month ago â Review: Nice and well sized indoor playground for kids. We booked a birthday party there for our 6 year old and some of his friends. There were a few tennage-aged employees who didn't seem to know what was going on. â  â The real kicker in all of this, is that after we checked out with the front desk and left, they later had trouble running our card for the remaining balance due, which resulted in the owner reporting us to the Centerville Police for theft. After speaking with a police detective, we (ofcourse) paid the unpaid invoice. It looks like they've already had to remove one of the guns at the T-Rex shooter thing. We struggled to get the one gun working. It did work, but it wasn't easy or reliably working.  It's too bad, because I feel like it's one of the coolest features here. â  â ----------------------- â  â Reviewer: Brandon Summers â Rating: 3/5 â Time: Edited 5 months ago â Review: Review from a member: Jurassic Jungle Playground is a fun spot, and our kids (7 and 4) absolutely love it! Thereâ€™s plenty to do, and it keeps them entertained. â  â However, there are a few drawbacks. As members, itâ€™s frustrating to have to book tickets so far in advance, which takes away some of the spontaneity of visiting. â  â The playground also isnâ€™t very well-suited for children under 3, as there arenâ€™t many activities geared toward younger kids, which I can see being challenging for some families with a combination of older and younger children. â  â Another issue is the requirement for adults to purchase special socks, even if theyâ€™re just sitting and not actively playing. This policy doesnâ€™t make much sense and feels like an unnecessary expense, especially for members. Including socks as part of the membership or revisiting this rule would be a welcome improvement. â  â It would also be great if there were â€œmember-onlyâ€ times to make the experience feel more exclusive and less crowded. â  â Overall, itâ€™s a fun place for kids but could benefit from better perks and convenience for members. 3.5/5 stars. â  â ----------------------- â  â Reviewer: Brandon Borget â Rating: 1/5 â Time: 5 months ago â Review: Thanksgiving Point is hustling their members with this new attraction. They allow insufficient tickets to be reserved by members while still allowing nonmembers to buy tickets. If tickets are not available online for members, they wonâ€™t let you in without paying. â  â ----------------------- â  â Reviewer: Eric martinez â Rating: 5/5 â Time: 5 months ago â Review: Honestly a pretty cool experience. For the price itâ€™s very similar to other indoor jungle gyms and the wristband for an extra $1.75 is worth it just to give the little kids something extra to do and to do the â€œmissionsâ€. My 3 year old loved it and we came at 10am on a Wednesday and it felt pretty busy so more popular times might get crowded. â  â Still a cool experience if your kid likes jungle gyms, slides and dinosaurs. Iâ€™d definitely come back. The gym itself is tall enough for adults to walk through with their kid for the most part pretty comfortably or if youâ€™re carrying a newborn then itâ€™s really simple as well. â  â Very well designed for the confined space itâ€™s in. â  â ----------------------- â  â Reviewer: Jennifer Nichol â Rating: 1/5 â Time: 5 months ago â Review: This place is such a money grab. So disappointing because my kids looove the new exhibit and think itâ€™s the best thing at the Dino museum. However, if youâ€™re a member, itâ€™s impossible to reserve tickets. Iâ€™ll go to website (before logging in as a member) and see all the availability open. And then I login and itâ€™s SOLD OUT for weeks on end. Soo when are the loyal thanksgiving point members with little kids get to enjoy it?? Weâ€™ve been members for nearly 7 years and come weekly to all the places. And this is how itâ€™s shaking out? Need to pay an additional price? Please update this member vs non member policy. â  â ----------------------- â  â Reviewer: Allie Johnson â Rating: 1/5 â Time: 5 months ago â Review: While the area itself is nice, it is really overcrowded if you donâ€™t arrive in the 9 AM slot. Taking all off that aside: â  â The biggest issue I have is that they have are not allowing members equal access to tickets without paying extra. This is the only Thanksgiving point venue where you cannot view available tickets without being logged into an account, and I finally figured out why. â  â If you log in with a member account the tickets are extremely limited, with almost nothing available on a given day, booked out to March. If you log in with a non-member account, many tickets are available day of. â  â Super shady considering members have already paid hundreds of dollars to access the facility. â  â How shady? Disney just paid out 9 million in a lawsuit for doing the same thing. â  â ----------------------- â  â Reviewer: Tori Snow â Rating: 4/5 â Time: 5 months ago â Review: We had my son's 3rd birthday party here and all the kids had a lot of fun. They just started doing birthday parties and definitely have some things they need to work out but nothing too major. We had to keep finding an employee to ask questions that were unclear, but they were always helpful. Also, be prepared to play with your younger kids because you cannot just sit at the waiting area and be able to see them. Even with being in the play structure the whole time I kept losing my 3 year old and having to chase him down. Luckily there is only one way out of the room it is in so you know they are somewhere near by, but it is VERY easy to lose your kids in just a second. â  â ----------------------- â  â Reviewer: Melissa Lutt â Rating: 2/5 â Time: 5 months ago â Review: We came 1/11/2025 so the venue hasnâ€™t even been open for a month but half the things seem to already be broken. My 6 yo son was super disappointed that he couldnâ€™t shoot the balls at the trex, half the badge scanners didnâ€™t work for the â€œmissionsâ€. For as crowded as it was both inside & out in the parking lot, this was really kind of a dud. Pretty bad when a 6 yo boy says heâ€™s done after an hour â  â ----------------------- â  â Reviewer: Natalie Griffiths â Rating: 2/5 â Time: 5 months ago â Review: I love Thanksgiving Point, we have been members for almost 8 years. However, this new venue is a big disappointment for several reasons. â 1. While several other Thanksgiving Point venues have done a great job catering to both older and younger kids, there is almost nothing for kids 2 and under to do. Jurassic Jungle totally missed the mark here. There are a few puffy â€œpillowsâ€ toddlers can climb on but they are placed on level 1 and 4 right in the middle of walkways, where many kids and adults are running and walking constantly. Having a low walled off area like the curiosity museum has for infants and toddlers could have been so easy. Could still be implemented in the dark and almost completely abandoned lava level or several other areas. But as it stands I wouldnâ€™t bring kids 2 and under here. The smallest green slide that looks like it was designed specifically for young kids, has a weird, slippery rock structure you have to climb over to get to it. Our 3 year old needs help with it every time. â 2. Unlike the rest of the Thanksgiving Point venues, children 2 and up need a ticket/paid entry. While you donâ€™t need a ticket until 3 at any other venue. First of all itâ€™s confusing and annoying, especially as members. Secondly, why are you charging $14 per person for a 2 year old who canâ€™t really play here? â 3. The design is incredibly flawed. They built it into the existing layout of the imax theater and it shows in a bad way. Itâ€™s almost completely stairs, with small landings that have little to entertain. There are 4 slides in the whole place, but ease of access for an adult is zero. It wouldnâ€™t have taken much to make at least some of the slides more accessible for small kids/adults as Iâ€™ve seen the big red multi-slide at places like Coconut Cove and Kangeroo Zoo. Those ones arenâ€™t hard for adults or smaller kids to access. This one is. â 4. Our sonâ€™s coat was stolen when we visited right before Christmas. I know it was opening week and it was crowded but it REALLY left a sour taste in my mouth about the whole place. Weâ€™ve never had anything like this happen in the hundreds of times weâ€™ve visited every other venue at Thanksgiving Point. So donâ€™t bring ANYTHING of value into the building. Leave it in your car. â 2 stars because my older 2 kids had a good time since they were ok to go through the structure as long as I stayed on the level 4 landing area and they could check in with me periodically. But like other reviewers have said, if you have kids under 5, either donâ€™t bring them or they need a 1:1 parent to child ratio. I agree wholeheartedly with another reviewer, I hope you consider involving parents in the design plans in the future as simple changes in design could have made this place a lot better. â  â ----------------------- â  â Reviewer: Jaimee Smart â Rating: 1/5 â Time: 5 months ago â Review: N/A â  â ----------------------- â  â Reviewer: R P â Rating: 3/5 â Time: 5 months ago â Review: They require grippy socks for kids and adults which is a little bizarre to me since I only went to sit while my kid played, but the actual area was entertaining enough. Another downside was how crazy expensive it is and you need to make a reservation. â  â ----------------------- â  â Reviewer: Brinn H â Rating: 4/5 â Time: 5 months ago â Review: I took my kids, ages 4, 7, &9 here today, and they had a great time playing for a couple of hours. They love dinosaurs, and the playground has lots of fun features, although I made them promise to stick together since it's closed off and easy to get lost from each other (and me sitting in the bench area). I wouldn't bring kids under 4 here, or at least plan to stay right with them the whole time. It's too bad there's no room for a play area for littles near the seating area. It's also fun to have a playground to hang out at when the weather is bad. â The wristbands are a fun feature for older kids, although extra cost. We're members, and I'm glad the admission is included with the membership, because we wouldn't pay the asking price for this as a stand-alone experience. We did have to make reservations in advance. â As a sidenote, the flashing lights, images and noises were overstimulating for my autistic/adhd 9-year-old, and there are stairs everywhere, so probably not accessible for those with mobility challenges. â  â ----------------------- â  â Reviewer: Kaycee Knaphus â Rating: 1/5 â Time: 5 months ago â Review: Terrible place for toddlers and young children. Loud, dark, chaotic, and crowded. They charge adults just to watch and make adults get grippy socks. Just go to the museum and skip this experience. This play place should be included in the price of admission to the museum. â  â ----------------------- â  â Reviewer: Savannah Woodall â Rating: 5/5 â Time: 5 months ago â Review: An incredible space for kids of all ages to learn. The concept turned experience was fascinating from the entrance to exit and everything in between. â  â ----------------------- â  â Reviewer: Daniel T â Rating: 3/5 â Time: 6 months ago â Review: My older kids had a lot of fun - it's really an impressive structure filled with so many fun things to look at and enjoy. Some things that we didn't like/didn't know: â  â â€¢ Charging for adults is dumb.  We're literally there supervising the kids.  Also hard to track your kids/kids to find you. â â€¢  We've only ever needed grip socks for the kids as long as we're only supervising, but they are required for everyone here. â â€¢ The biggest gripe I have was that I have a little one (18 mo) and our friends had two 12mo twins.  While the older kids were playing, it was impossible to find a place where they could play without getting run over by the older kids.  There's that one "hall" at the top of the stairs by the rotating circle that had some pieces that little ones could play on, but we found that the older kids would step on the little one's hands and thankfully never fell on or ran over any of them.  Not sure why they didn't design in a small separate area for 3 and under like they have done over at the curiosity museum?  That seems to me like a smart addition since families often have a smattering of ages to accommodate. â â€¢ Lastly, they should allow people in for 2 hour slots so it doesn't get too over-crowded.  Similar to what they do at the trampoline parks.  They say that they have to be careful for fire code, but they just let more and more people in during the day, so I don't quite understand this. â  â ----------------------- â  â Reviewer: Mia Archer â Rating: 3/5 â Time: 6 months ago â Review: We attended yesterday (1/2/25) and our kids enjoyed it for the most part, but if you have older kids it may not keep their attention for that long. My kids (ages 8-14) completed the wristband missions within 30 minutes and after that theyâ€™re like â€œummm what do we do now.â€ We had to come up with games for them to play so we could at least stay for an hour. That was my kids, I know all kids are not the same. But when the kids approach the older years this may not keep their attention for long so be warned. â  â The structure is cool, itâ€™s very large and thereâ€™s lots of areas for adults to sit inside. However, it is pretty dark in there and some areas are darker than others. I nearly fell off a triangle shaped step because I couldnâ€™t see it from the main floor. And I almost took a little girl with me, luckily I caught myself and was able to grab her too before we both went down. There needs to be some reflective tape or something on steps that separate the floor from steps. â  â I donâ€™t think adults should be charged a full price, maybe just $5 if they go into the structure and nothing if their kids are older and donâ€™t need supervising. I also think if the tickets are timed entry, people need to leave after a certain block of time too. It was extremely crowded in there. I felt bad for a man we met outside, he had driven from afar to bring his little boy and they wouldnâ€™t let him in because he didnâ€™t know he had to reserve online. With how many kids were in there Iâ€™m sure they could have sold him a ticket. Very sad. â  â I see a lot of parents complaining that it was easy for their little ones to get lost- it does say online that this structure is better suited for older kids. So thatâ€™s your mistake if you let your little one loose alone in here, this play structure is HUGE and Iâ€™d never let a kid younger than 4 roam it alone. â  â Overall I do think the price for kids is fair, and it is fun! Some minor improvements just need to be made. â  â ----------------------- â  â Reviewer: Sam Bush â Rating: 5/5 â Time: 6 months ago â Review: N/A â  â ----------------------- â  â Reviewer: Samantha Rawson â Rating: 5/5 â Time: 6 months ago â Review: This place is awesome. I am a member of Thanksgiving point and it makes sense that at least for now there are reservations and a limit to how many people can be in there at once. I imagine that since this is a new place and very popular they will be restricting access for a while until the hype cools down just as I am sure they did when opening their other indoor playground. Also, I do NOT like how they make adults pay for admission. I literally was in there keeping track of my toddlers. Wearing grip socks are one thing, but making adults pay admission is nuts! This place has gone up drastically! I love thanksgiving point, and Iâ€™ll continue coming but I do ask for some improving dog sure. â  â ----------------------- â  â Reviewer: Connor Patterson â Rating: 5/5 â Time: 6 months ago â Review: Everyone else is wrong. Oh look an indoor playground in Utah county thatâ€™s just opened and itâ€™s 12 degrees outside. I wonder if it will be crowded? Or loud? Or hard to book a reservation? Duh. â  â ----------------------- â  â Reviewer: Jared Choate â Rating: 1/5 â Time: 6 months ago â Review: Speaking as a member who gets free admission, itâ€™s not worth it. The whole thing is a joke. â  â Booking makes the entire experience a nightmare. Every other venue at Thanksgiving Point is a breeze for members, you walk in and scan and youâ€™re good. To enter here, you need a reservation. That means you need to go online and reserve from a limited number of tickets. Tickets are always sold out weeks in advance. â  â We got a ticket for our son since literally every other play jungle in the area is just paying for the child. After planning the whole day around it, purchasing the wristband to go with it, we get to the front and they say we all need tickets. Even the adults. There was literally only one ticket available online. After talking to several people they informed us there was literally nothing they could do to remedy the situation. According to the fire code they have to limit the number of people. â  â Now you might think â€œwell the fire code is the law so that makes senseâ€. If you donâ€™t think about it any deeper than that, youâ€™d be correct. However, considering that literally none of the other playground places have obvious limits, and considering that the Jurassic Jungle doesnâ€™t give you a time limit to play, itâ€™s ridiculous to assume they can control occupancy by selling only a certain amount of tickets. â  â If they sell 500 tickets per day, they can say they control occupancy by controlling time of entry, which they donâ€™t, and provide a time to leave, which they donâ€™t. That means in theory all 500 ticket holders could show up at the same time. Then you could say â€œwell maybe occupancy is 500 at any given time so they planned that outâ€ which makes sense except for the fact that if you donâ€™t have max occupancy at the same time, you can let others in. The system in place to control occupancy is extremely flawed, outdated, frustrating, and removes any excitement there is about the new attraction. â  â If this is this difficult for members, I canâ€™t imagine how frustrating it would be to pay for a ticket, show up, and have them tell you you wasted your money because they forgot to tell you the adults also need tickets. â  â I expected more. I expected better. â  â ----------------------- â  â Reviewer: Larry Fullenwider â Rating: 1/5 â Time: 6 months ago â Review: Thanksgiving Point has become a joke. It's a let's cater to the rich, high income tax bracket, nickle and dime everyone else. Build a Carousel, COOL!! Downside? Charge you for it even though you have admission. It's more of pay for our membership. When it first opened they even charged members for it, until they got a crap ton of pushback. EBT doesn't apply to anything new, their new Dino playground is $14 a kid plus make adults pay to "watch" your child. Family of 5 with wristbands, socks and admission is $60!!! Members are free, but not wristbands , required grip socks are not free and have to make a reservation. At this point the membership is becoming useless. Mountain America funded it. Which means they ought to make it available to more people. They use to be for the community now it's a frickin money grab. Also let's also point out the fact that practically nothing allows kids in wheelchairs to access their bigger attractions. They're pretty much confined to certain areas because of the non accessibility playground, especially in the Museum of Natural Curiosity, I struggle to bring my 4 year old Spina Bifida kid here because she gets frustrated not being able to do what her siblings get to do. This won't solve anything though, it'll get seen and they'll continue to get their money, and not change a thing. â  â ----------------------- â  â Reviewer: Ashley Hess â Rating: 3/5 â Time: 6 months ago â Review: This is a fun playground and my kids did enjoy it. It does need some improvements to match up with other indoor playgrounds Iâ€™ve been to. For example, I donâ€™t feel adults should pay admission fees or need no grip socks unless they are playing with their kids on the play structure. Iâ€™ve been to similar indoor playgrounds and Iâ€™ve never had to pay for myself or have grip socks. Also, it is really hard to monitor young children, the playground itself is super closed off. Maybe adding some cameras throughout with screens where the adults sit would help. Iâ€™ve also seen this at similar playgrounds and it helps a lot. To sum it up, my kids enjoyed it, but there needs to be some definite improvements on what people are charged. â  â ----------------------- â  â Reviewer: Caitlin Smith â Rating: 3/5 â Time: 6 months ago â Review: I'm only giving three stars because this place was FUN, AFFORDABLE, and CLEAN. Other than that, everything else was pretty much subpar. It's fairly dark and loud, so definitely easy to lose your kids. It's designed for older kids, obviously, so pretty much every parent has to go in with their child, making the playground even more crowded. My biggest issue was with the online ticketing system, which is such a joke! We made reservations ahead of time and paid for the tickets and even signed all of the waivers before we arrived, and we STILL ended up having to wait in line for forever to get in! What was the point? And they clearly only care about profit. They sold waaaaay more tickets than they should have. The place was packed and overcrowded. No exaggeration - you couldn't walk a foot in any direction without running into a child. Many children were getting lost and sobbing as workers had to help them find their parents. It's just very overstimulating and crowded. We still had fun but probably wouldn't go again unless they can figure out the ticketing and check in issues. Not to mention, EVERY PERSON going in needs grip socks, whether you're going into the playground or not. Another $3/person cash grab. Many people don't need the socks..some moms sat at the bottom nursing their infants while their older kids played but still had to have the special socks. â  â Long story short..keep an eye on your child for every single second, bring the socks, and reserve plenty of time ahead and you should be fine, if you enjoy way overcrowded dark playgrounds â  â ----------------------- â  â Reviewer: Austin Locke â Rating: 5/5 â Time: 6 months ago â Review: Awesome concept and playground. A really nice addition to the museum â  â ----------------------- â  â Reviewer: Briana Thomas â Rating: 5/5 â Time: 6 months ago â Review: This is a fun new feature. As members we made advanced reservations online a few weeks ago and didn't have any issues. It was clear that we had to bring grippy socks when we made the reservation. â  â I like the interactive story they put in with the wristbands. It would be awesome if they incorporated it throughout the rest of the museum. â  â They had a lot of staff on the structures. It seems as though they are still working out some of the kinks since it is new. â  â I think they made the best usage of the space however the fact this is the old movie theatre seems to pose limitations on the layout. It is difficult for parents to see and keep tabs on children if you are not climbing on the structure with them and there is not a separate area for young toddlers. â  â I would not take a small toddler or any child with sensory issues as it is extreme sensory overload with My 3 and 7 year olds were done after an hour. â  â ----------------------- â  â Reviewer: Erika Barbosa â Rating: 1/5 â Time: 6 months ago â Review: Not worth it. This place was extremely packed. The design is definitely for bigger kids not at all for kids under 3.. Not sure why they do the time slots either. Thanksgiving is just extremely expensive at this point. â  â ----------------------- â  â Reviewer: nic rou â Rating: 5/5 â Time: 6 months ago â Review: This place is very fun and exciting. Itâ€™s a pretty good size for my seven year old niece to run around in. Make sure you dress you and your kid in layers. I run warm so I got hot within 15 minutes- I was playing too. â There in a water fountain and a wheelchair ramp. Staff was attentive looking out for lost kids. I do wish there were tvs that show different angles of the playground so you could keep an eye out, like Kidtopia has. We will be back :) â  â ----------------------- â  â Reviewer: Kadison Thompson â Rating: 3/5 â Time: 6 months ago â Review: Weâ€™ve been super excited for the new Dino playground (Jurassic Jungle). It is fun for older kids; however, there isnâ€™t anything for kids under 2 unless youâ€™re willing to climb in with them. Itâ€™s also a bit overstimulating with the dinosaur sounds, dim lighting, etc. I also think itâ€™s crazy they charge $14 per kid. It was fun but unless you buy the wristband (which costs even more) youâ€™re paying $14 for some slides and climbing equipment, which you can also get at a bunch of other play areas throughout Utah county. Again, itâ€™s fun but Iâ€™m getting a little frustrated with how much money Thanksgiving Point charges for everything. Oh last thing-I think itâ€™s funny they charge for adults when literally all youâ€™re doing is chasing yours kids around trying not to lose them in the various playground levels. I think adults should be free. â  â ----------------------- â  â Reviewer: Dr. Omana â Rating: 5/5 â Time: 6 months ago â Review: So much fun! A great interactive play ground that will keep your kids happy for hours! â  â ----------------------- â  â Reviewer: Helen Cornia â Rating: 5/5 â Time: 6 months ago â Review: Great place for kids to play. Online reservations are easy and tickets are free for members. Plan ahead for a fun time. Wristbands (not essential) and brought our own grip socks - you will need them. Wasn't as crowded as anticipated being opening week. â  â ----------------------- â  â Reviewer: jadilyn walker â Rating: 1/5 â Time: 6 months ago â Review: Booking system is a joke. Over a week is booked out and the available time slots only have 1 ticket which doesnâ€™t work because even if you only have 1 kid you need a ticket for yourself too. â So if I want to use it I have to pay. â I already have a membership, Iâ€™m not going to pay more. And also charging for kids older than 2 is ridiculous when my kid is free to get in to the museum. Hopefully they completely change this system because this is NOT IT. â  â ----------------------- â  â Reviewer: Melissa Stapleton â Rating: 1/5 â Time: 6 months ago â Review: HUGE bummer that paying non-members are prioritized over those with memberships. Seems backwards. â To clarify, I understand the reservation system. The problem is there were open slots available at almost every time interval that I looked up for paying non -members. But no open slots for those with memberships. I have to wait two weeks to get in. â  â ----------------------- â  â Reviewer: Rick Larsen â Rating: 5/5 â Time: 6 months ago â Review: N/A â  â ----------------------- â  â Reviewer: J. â Rating: 2/5 â Time: 6 months ago â Review: RELEVANT TO MEMBERS: we are members of Thanksgiving Point, three of us arrived December 17th to experience the new venue. Nonslip socks are required was the first thing we learned, but more importantly we found out that 'Without an advanced reservation, even as a member, you will be charged full price for admittance' according to the representative of the counter. She went on to explain that 'we are still trying to figure out how many guests are safe in the jungle, so we charge members full price for admission if the limited spots to reserve are full.' It was something like $14 per child and $5 per adult. I asked, so charging members is a deterrent for them to visit and limits your visitors? And how soon will you know how many people are safe in the venue? Doesn't the fire marshal need to establish that? I'm guessing the manager or supervisor behind the counter in Black stepped up immediately and tried to explain to me that Thanksgiving Point is still trying to pay for the new venue, and since it's so busy they are charging because there are safety implications if they allow too many people in. I asked her how long this will be happening, and she said advanced reservation will be required permanently going forward after I repeated my question (hmm not for a time). I asked how much time is considered advanced notice for a reservation, and she didn't understand, so I said again is an hour advanced, a day, or a year considered advanced notice of our visit? She said as long as we reserve it online it is considered advanced reservation. I also asked her to clarify why they would let people in past capacity if it's not safe. She repeated that they are trying to pay for the new venue, and they need to limit the number of people coming in. I repeated my question more clearly, I asked why they wouldn't close the venue if it's already reached 100% capacity due to the safety concerns? Why would they continually allow people to go in just because they are paying money? I was anticipating reporting them to the fire marshal immediately. She did concede that they would close the venue if it was beyond safety and they reached 100% capacity. But this confirms, they just want to charge more money even to members. This is bull crap, the venue is already paid for and they just want to charge extra money. Quite the grand opening, what a nasty and bitter taste this leaves in my mouth about Thanksgiving Point. â  â PLEASE do not pay anything extra as a member. Drive about 10 minutes south to Coconut Cove and pay $10 for children over the age of three, $5 for children under the age of three for unlimited play all day. And join me in reserving only when it is 'free' to members who have already paid for the venue with their membership. There should be free socks at least for the grand opening. â About an hour after I walked away from the counter without paying, I got a notification from their app that members need to reserve in advance. Hopefully I get through to management, what a crappy grab at more cash. I feel the same about Luminaria. Ashton Gardens is worthless during the winter, in other words it is their slow season, so they charge even more money to members to bring lights to the garden when nothing is in bloom instead of just putting up lights to encourage people to visit they charge even more money so their garden's slow season is now probably it's most profitable.}

The staff was great, it was a fun place, pretty clean, and pretty good equipment - though it's not well lit, the drinking fountains were broken, and it was pretty cold inside. We had fun playing for my son's birthday party, but their party policies are unclear and confusing. Nowhere, when I booked the party (which includes entrance for 10 kids), did it say you can only arrive 5 minutes prior to the room reservation, which I didn't appreciate because I wanted to schedule the room for 5:00pm but couldn't because that wasn't an option (even though no one had the room booked before us) and we wanted to start the party then and play before eating pizza and cake at 6:00 (playing before eating, so kids don't get sick). It took several phone calls and convincing the manager to let us play before our room reservation (even though when we got there, there was almost no one else there). The website and signs on the door say "No outside food or drink", but then there is a place to eat food and the other guests I saw there were eating outside food, so it's stated everywhere but not enforced? For the party, we couldn't bring outside food (aside from the cake and water bottles), and had to order through them. BUT they only offered a couple kinds of pizza, and it turns out, they just go buy it from Marco's in Lindon. Good pizza, but why couldn't I buy it from Marco's or anywhere else myself and bring it in? Then I would've been able to have more choices than just pepperoni or cheese pizza. Plus, the staff member who went to pick it up got lost so we couldn't start our pizza party in the room until 25 minutes after our scheduled time anyway (poor kids were getting hungry). I asked if we could bring in a veggie or fruit tray (minimal mess and something healthy) and they absolutely refused saying it was against policy, but they don't offer anything healthy, just the pizza and juice boxes. I assumed they would have enough plates for us since we ordered 8 pizzas, but they only provided 10 plates for the kids (I guess adults don't get plates). I didn't know so I didn't bring our own and then they charge 50 cents a paper plate if you want any extras. It's truly wild! So yeah, the play place is safe and fun for the kids to play, but their party policies are nuts and don't make any sense, so I can't fully recommend it, for a birthday party, at least. â And FYI, the party rooms are pretty small so the kids fit fine but the adults were crowded around the edges just standing with only a few able to sit. â  â ----------------------- â  â Reviewer: Rebecca Peterson â Rating: 5/5 â Time: 7 months ago â Review: My toddler loved this place, very clean and friendly staff. â  â ----------------------- â  â Reviewer: Courtney Bengry â Rating: 3/5 â Time: 8 months ago â Review: Visited for our first time today and my kids absolutely loved it, itâ€™s clean and my kids could have spent all day here, however, the only thing that was disappointing was it isnâ€™t allergy friendly.
